FLECS: A Federated Learning Second-Order Framework via Compression and Sketching

Artem Agafonov Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence, Abu Dhabi, UAE Dmitry Kamzolov Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence, Abu Dhabi, UAE Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia Rachael Tappenden University of Canterbury, Christchurch 8041, New Zealand Alexander Gasnikov Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia Institute for Information Transmission Problems, Moscow, Russia HSE University, Moscow, Russia Martin Takáč Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence, Abu Dhabi, UAE
Abstract

Inspired by the recent work FedNL (Safaryan et al, FedNL: Making Newton-Type Methods Applicable to Federated Learning), we propose a new communication efficient second-order framework for Federated learning, namely FLECS. The proposed method reduces the high-memory requirements of FedNL by the usage of an L-SR1 type update for the Hessian approximation which is stored on the central server. A low dimensional ‘sketch’ of the Hessian is all that is needed by each device to generate an update, so that memory costs as well as number of Hessian-vector products for the agent are low. Biased and unbiased compressions are utilized to make communication costs also low. Convergence guarantees for FLECS are provided in both the strongly convex, and nonconvex cases, and local linear convergence is also established under strong convexity. Numerical experiments confirm the practical benefits of this new FLECS algorithm.

1 Introduction

This paper presents a novel second-order method for Federated Learning called FLECS. In this setup, multiple agents/devices/workers collaborate to solve a machine learning problem by communicating over a central node (server). It is assumed that the central node is a large and powerful machine, but the agents/devices are much smaller (for example, a cellphone, or laptop). Moreover, raw data is stored locally on each worker and cannot be exchanged or transferred. The finite sum minimization, or Federated Learning, problem can be formalized in the following way:

minw∈ℝd⁡{F​(w):=1n​∑i=1nfi​(w)},subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑assign𝐹𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤\textstyle{\min}_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left\{F(w):=\tfrac{1}{n}\textstyle{\sum}_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(w)\right\}, (1)

where fi​(w)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑤f_{i}(w) is the loss function (parametrized by w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}) associated with the data stored on the i𝑖i-th machine, F​(w)𝐹𝑤F(w) is the empirical loss function, and both the problem dimension d𝑑d, and the number of machines n𝑛n, can be large.
Problems of the form (1) arise not only in distributed machine learning [23, 24], but also in robotics, resource allocation, power system control, control of drone or satellite networks, distributed statistical inference and optimal transport, and multi-agent reinforcement learning [39, 33, 28, 14, 37, 35].
A variety of first-ordered methods have been introduced for the problem (1) under the stated computational set-up (a central server connected to multiple smaller devices). Early work includes that of [10, 11, 26], which focused on distributed first order optimization algorithms that were designed with the computational structure in mind. Recent advances include works focusing on reducing the communication burden via compression techniques [2, 19, 9], including momentum for algorithm speed up [27, 43], variance reduction techniques [20], the use of adaptive learning rates [40], and works that focus on maintaining client data privacy [16].
Beyond first-order methods, second-order methods have also been developed for Federated Learning. Some of these algorithms [42, 15, 12, 5, 1] utilize statistical similarity (the homogeneous data setting), which, roughly speaking, means that the local functions fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} are similar, and they approximate the overall empirical risk function F𝐹F well. FedNL [36] for the second-order method for Federated Learning in the case of heterogeneous data. While FedNL makes a valuable step toward the applicability of second-order methods to Federated Learning, this framework seems to be impractical for large-scaled problems, since d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d Hessian approximations are stored locally on workers and transferred to the server via compressed matrix communications. (This violates the assumption in the current work, that the individual workers have small memory.)
The goal here is to build upon the work in [36] and develop a new second order framework for Federated Learning that is based upon more realistic assumptions about the available computational architecture. That is, we assume that individual workers are devices with relatively low memory availability and computational capacity (e.g. mobile phones), but they can connect to a large and powerful central machine. The typical situation, that downloading is much faster than uploading, is also assumed. 111 An example of such a setting is (e.g., battery powered) wireless network [34, 41] where the cost of sending data from devices to the centralized server is energy demanding, implying severely limited communication bandwidth to the server [18, 8]. On the other hand, the server is usually connected to an energy network and has no constraints for sending data to other devices in the network. We introduce the FLECS second-order framework for strongly convex and non-convex optimization, which places no additional memory on workers and reduces the number Hessian-vector products per node. Therefore, our algorithm can be viewed as the lightweight FedNL, since it provides similar theoretical guarantees and has almost the same global. FLECS uses sketching [38] and matrix compression for efficient communication and allows for several Hessian learning techniques (including truncated LSR1 update) and two iterate updates, namely Truncated inverse Hessian approximation and FedSONIA, inspired by [30] and [22].

1.1 Contributions

We propose FLECS: a Federated LEarning Second-Order Framework via Compression and Sketching with the following properties.

  • •

    No additional storage on workers. In large-scale machine learning problems, it is impossible to store the d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d-dimensional Hessian approximations. For a dataset with d=50,000𝑑50000d=50,000 features, the local Hessian approximation requires more than 101010 GB of memory. For FLECS, the Hessian approximations are stored on the server, so memory requirements for the individual workers remain low.

  • •

    Efficient communication via sketching and compression. To reduce the cost of communication, we use a sketching technique. This allows the exchange of d×m𝑑𝑚d\times m matrices instead of d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d, where m≪dmuch-less-than𝑚𝑑m\ll d is the user defined memory size, which could be set as m=1𝑚1m=1. Moreover, we exploit compression to make the algorithm even more communication-efficient. This strategy heavily improves the one in [36], since we decrease the dimension of the transferred matrices d/m𝑑𝑚d/m times. Moreover, sketching reduces the number of Hessian-vector products from d𝑑d to m𝑚m.

  • •

    Heterogeneous data setting. Our framework is flexible and does not assume that data on the workers is independent and identically distributed.

  • •

    Hessian Learning via Quasi-Newton updates. Motivated by quasi-Newton methods, sketching techniques and inverse Hessian truncation, we propose the Truncated L-SR1 update and Direct update for our Hessian approximations.

  • •

    Theoretical Analysis. Convergence guarantees in both the strongly convex, and nonconvex cases, are provided, as well as a local linear rate of convergence under strong convexity independent of problem conditioning.

  • •

    Competitive Numerical Experiments. Our numerical experiments highlight the practical benefits of our proposed framework.

Organization.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. Related works are described in Section 2. Section 3 presents the proposed framework, including all algorithmic details. In Section 4, we establish theoretical convergence guarantees (all proofs can be found in the appendix). Numerical experiments are provided in Section 5 (additional experiments are provided in the appendix), and concluding remarks and potential future research directions are given in Section 6.

2 Related Work

Second-order methods are well established in the optimization literature. Such methods employ the Hessian (or an approximation to it) and thereby important (possibly approximate and/or partial) curvature information is available for utilization. The benefits include ‘better’ search directions, and faster rates of convergence that may be independent of the condition number, although the algorithms often have higher memory and computational requirements than first order methods. To balance the trade off between improved convergence rates versus increased costs, approaches that involve modifying or approximating the Hessian have been proposed, and several of these are discussed now.
Arguably, some of the most popular algorithms that use approximations to the Hessian are quasi-Newton methods. They employ information from the iterates to build an approximation to the Hessian that improves in accuracy as the algorithm progresses. Among these are algorithms that use BFGS, SR1, and DFP updates [17, 29, 13], which are now considered to be classics in optimization due to their effectiveness and practicality, and also because, under certain conditions, theoretical results related to the accuracy of the Hessian approximations are available. This motivates the current work, which incorporates quasi-Newton type updates to learn a good approximation to the Hessian.
Of particular interest is the SR1 update, which does not guarantee positive definiteness of the Hessian approximation [13]. Previously, this was considered to be a disadvantage, but in the case of non-convex optimization, it would appear to be advantageous. L-SR1, a limited memory variant of SR1, belongs to the class of limited memory quasi-Newton algorithms [25, 4]. These methods store only the last m𝑚m gradient differences Yk=[yk−m+1,…,yk]subscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘𝑚1…subscript𝑦𝑘Y_{k}=[y_{k-m+1},\ldots,y_{k}] and iterate differences Sk=[sk−m+1,…,sk]subscript𝑆𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘𝑚1…subscript𝑠𝑘S_{k}=[s_{k-m+1},\ldots,s_{k}], where m𝑚m is the memory size, yk=∇F​(wk)−∇F​(wk−1)subscript𝑦𝑘∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘1y_{k}=\nabla F(w_{k})-\nabla F(w_{k-1}) and sk=wk−wk−1subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘1s_{k}=w_{k}-w_{k-1}. The compact form of the L-SR1 update is [6]

Bk=B0+(Yk−B0​Sk)​Mk−1​(Yk−B0​Sk)T,subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝐵0subscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝐵0subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝐵0subscript𝑆𝑘𝑇B_{k}=B_{0}+(Y_{k}-B_{0}S_{k})M_{k}^{-1}(Y_{k}-B_{0}S_{k})^{T}, (2)

where Mk=Lk+Dk+LkT−SkT​B0​Sksubscript𝑀𝑘subscript𝐿𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑘𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑇subscript𝐵0subscript𝑆𝑘M_{k}=L_{k}+D_{k}+L_{k}^{T}-S_{k}^{T}B_{0}S_{k}, SkT​Yk=Lk+Dk+Uksuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑇subscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝐿𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑈𝑘~{}S_{k}^{T}Y_{k}=L_{k}+D_{k}+U_{k}, Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is diagonal, Lksubscript𝐿𝑘L_{k}, Uksubscript𝑈𝑘U_{k} are strictly lower and upper triangular, and B0subscript𝐵0B_{0} is the initial approximation.
The work [3] proposed the use of a sampled Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}, rather than one based upon the previous m𝑚m iterate differences. The idea is, given the current iterate wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}, simply sample m𝑚m random directions, and use the differences with wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} as the columns of sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} (forming Yksubscript𝑌𝑘Y_{k} appropriately). An Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} with this form can be viewed as sketching matrix [38], and the Newton Sketch algorithm in [31], shows that even randomly projected or a sub-sampled Hessian provides enough curvature information for fast convergence.
The Nonconvex Newton method of [30] is a different approach, which is an adaptation of Newton’s method for nonconvex problems. At each iteration, the singular value decomposition of the Hessian is computed, small eigenvalues (in absolute value) are truncated, and then a positive definite modification of the Hessian is constructed. This is then used to create Newton-type direction.
SONIA [22] bridges the gap between first-order and second-order methods, combining the ideas of quasi-Newton algorithms, sketching [31] and truncation [30]. It constructs the search directions using curvature information in one subspace and gradient information in the orthogonal complement.
Second-order methods for Federated Learning, can generally be divided in two groups, based upon whether a homogeneous or heterogeneous data setting is assumed. Algorithms in the first group rely on the concept of statistical similarity, which, in practice, means that each local function fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} is a ‘good’ approximation of the global objective function F𝐹F. (More formally, ‖∇2F−∇2fi‖≤βnormsuperscript∇2𝐹superscript∇2subscript𝑓𝑖𝛽\|\nabla^{2}F-\nabla^{2}f_{i}\|\leq\beta for some β>0𝛽0\beta>0.) Usually, in this case, methods utilize the part of the data stored on the server and use it to approximate the full Hessian [42, 15, 12, 5, 1].
No such statistical similarity (i.i.d.) assumption is made in the heterogeneous setting, which is perhaps more realistic (e.g., it may be impossible/impractical to have local data (on a mobile phone say), that approximates the data on the server well). The main work in this setting is FedNL [36]. The authors proposed a way to learn Hessian approximations and then take an approximate Newton-type step. However, the main drawback is that the Hessian approximations are stored locally and communications performed via compressed d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d matrices. For large-scale optimization problems, it is impossible to store the d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d matrix locally, because of memory limitations. Extensions of FedNL can be found in [21], [32].
The approach proposed here combines ideas from quasi-Newton methods, sketching, and Hessian learning, and develops a second-order Federated Learning framework with efficient communications and without an additional memory burden on workers. All Hessian approximations are stored on the server, not the workers. Communications are based on a user-defined memory hyperparameter m𝑚m and utilize compression to reduce communication. Sketching allows to transfer d×m𝑑𝑚d\times m matrices and reduce the number of Hessian-vector products on the worker. The proposed framework allows for two Hessian learning techniques and two iterate update rules. The Truncated Inverse Hessian approximation is based on the idea of truncating eigenvalues (as in [30]) of Hessian approximate, while FedSONIA is based upon SONIA [22] and reduces the iteration complexity of the step from O​(d3)𝑂superscript𝑑3O(d^{3}) to O​(n​m​d2)𝑂𝑛𝑚superscript𝑑2O(nmd^{2}).

3 FLECS

Inspired by the works [22, 36], we propose a general framework for second-order methods for federated learning problems (1) that allows for different forms for the iterates and different Hessian approximations/updates. One of main goals of this framework is to create fast communication-efficient second-order methods that do not place additional memory requirements on the workers.
To make broadcasting between the server and nodes cheap we employ sketching and compression. Throughout the paper, Sk∈ℝd×msubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚S_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} denotes a sketching matrix, where m𝑚m is the memory size (m≪dmuch-less-than𝑚𝑑m\ll d). Any operator that compresses a matrix is denoted by 𝒞:ℝd×m→ℝd×m:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}\to\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} , e.g. random dithering, Rank-R𝑅R, Top-K𝐾K, Rand-K𝐾K (description of compressors can be found in Appendix C). The Hessian approximation of the i𝑖i-th worker at iteration k𝑘k is denoted by Bkisuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑖B_{k}^{i}, and is stored on the central node.
Our framework can be described in three steps (further details follow in later subsections):

The matrix is sent directly (i.e., no compression), since, typically, downloading is faster than uploading. 3.1 Initialization

The algorithm is initialized with a user defined memory size m≪dmuch-less-than𝑚𝑑m\ll d, and n𝑛n matrices B0i∈ℝd×dsuperscriptsubscript𝐵0𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑B_{0}^{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} are stored on the central node, each representing an approximation to the local Hessian for the i𝑖ith worker. Various additional parameters are initialized depending on the selected update rule (to be described later). At iteration k>0𝑘0k>0 of FLECS, m𝑚m directions {s1,…,sm}subscript𝑠1…subscript𝑠𝑚\left\{s_{1},\ldots,s_{m}\right\} are randomly sampled at all nodes (including the server) and combined together, forming the columns of a sketching matrix Sk∈ℝd×msubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚S_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}. Note that Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} is the same for all machines and the main node; this is guaranteed by setting the random seed to be equal to the iteration number k𝑘k during sampling.

Search direction option 1. Truncated inverse Hessian approximation (Algorithm 3). Here, Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k} is taken to be the truncated inverse Hessian approximation (|Bk+1|ωΩ)−1superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘1𝜔Ω1\left(|B_{k+1}|_{\omega}^{\Omega}\right)^{-1}. Consider the following.

Definition 1.

Let Bk,Vk,Λksubscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘subscriptΛ𝑘B_{k},V_{k},\Lambda_{k} be matrices such that Bk=Vk​Λk​VkTsubscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑉𝑘subscriptΛ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑘𝑇B_{k}=V_{k}\Lambda_{k}V_{k}^{T}, and let 0<ω≤Ω0𝜔Ω0<\omega\leq\Omega. Definition 1 was proposed in [30] and was used to provide a convergence guarantee for their Nonconvex Newton method (to a local minimum). Firstly, an eigen-decomposition of Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} is computed, but with every eigenvalue replaced by its absolute value. Secondly, a thresholding step is applied, so that any eigenvalue (in absolute value) that is smaller (resp. greater) than a user defined threshold ω𝜔\omega (resp. ΩΩ\Omega) is replaced by ω𝜔\omega (resp. ΩΩ\Omega). This truncation is crucial for several reasons. Firstly, it ensures Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} is well-defined, which leads to stable updates. Secondly, it ensures that after truncation, the resulting matrix will be full-rank and positive definite. Therefore, it guarantees that the following search direction is a decent direction

pk=(|Bk+1|ωΩ)−1​∇F​(wk).subscript𝑝𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘1𝜔Ω1∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘p_{k}=\left(|B_{k+1}|_{\omega}^{\Omega}\right)^{-1}\nabla F(w_{k}). (11)

Search direction option 2. FedSONIA (Algorithm 4). FedSONIA is a modification of SONIA [22] that is adapted to the Federated Learning setting. The key idea of SONIA is to utilize curvature information in one subspace and perform a gradient step in orthogonal complement. The intuition is that, by incorporating some curvature information the resulting search direction should be ‘better’ than a pure gradient direction, but the user has control over the dimension of each subspace, and therefore they have control over the cost of obtaining the curvature information. Truncation (Definition 1) and modified SR1 update (eq. (6)) ensure that the Hessian-approximation is full-rank, positive and well defined, which is crucial to avoid checking condition on the curvature pairs YkT​Sksuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘𝑇subscript𝑆𝑘Y_{k}^{T}S_{k} (Y~kT​Sksuperscriptsubscript~𝑌𝑘𝑇subscript𝑆𝑘\widetilde{Y}_{k}^{T}S_{k} for FedSONIA). To construct the approximation of the Hessian we use (8). Note, that SONIA does not need the Hessian approximation Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} itself to commit a step. Instead, it utilizes only Hessian-matrix product Yksubscript𝑌𝑘Y_{k} and sketching matrix Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}.

Complexity. The per iteration complexity of FLECS depends on the chosen options for both the Hessian approximation and the iterate updates. The complexity of the Truncated L-SR1 update for one Hessian approximation consists of matrix products (O​(m​d2))𝑂𝑚superscript𝑑2(O(md^{2})) and a singular value decomposition of m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m matrix (O​(m3))𝑂superscript𝑚3(O(m^{3})). For the Direct update, the matrix products cost O​(m​d2)𝑂𝑚superscript𝑑2O(md^{2}) and forming the pseudo-inverse of the m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m matrix costs O​(m3)𝑂superscript𝑚3O(m^{3}). Therefore, the total complexity of either Hessian approximation update is O​(n​m​d2)𝑂𝑛𝑚superscript𝑑2O(nmd^{2}). The complexity of computing search direction via Truncated inverse Hessian approximation is O​(d3)𝑂superscript𝑑3O(d^{3}), since we utilize spectral decomposition and products of d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d matrices. FedSONIA update comprises 1) QR factorization (O​(d​m2))𝑂𝑑superscript𝑚2(O(dm^{2})); 2) pseudoinverse of m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m matrix (O​(m3))𝑂superscript𝑚3(O(m^{3})); 3) spectral decomposition of m×m𝑚𝑚m\times m matrix (O​(m2))𝑂superscript𝑚2(O(m^{2})); which gives total complexity O​(d​m2)𝑂𝑑superscript𝑚2O(dm^{2}). Finally, the complexity of FLECS on the server only depends on options for the search direction and equals O​(d3+n​m​d2)𝑂superscript𝑑3𝑛𝑚superscript𝑑2O(d^{3}+nmd^{2}) for Truncated Inverse Hessian approximation and O​(n​m​d2)𝑂𝑛𝑚superscript𝑑2O(nmd^{2}) for FedSONIA. The the worker step’s complexity consists of m𝑚m Hessian-vector products and matrix multiplication (O​(m​d2))𝑂𝑚superscript𝑑2(O(md^{2})).

4 FLECS: Convergence Theory

In this section, convergence theory for our FLECS framework is presented. We provide global convergence results in both the strongly convex, and nonconvex cases. A local convergence result is also presented, which shows local linear convergence of the iterates under strong convexity. We define w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} to be the initial point, w⋆=arg⁡minw∈ℝd⁡F​(w)superscript𝑤⋆subscript𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝑤w^{\star}=\arg\min\limits_{w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F(w) and F⋆=F​(w⋆)superscript𝐹⋆𝐹superscript𝑤⋆F^{\star}=F(w^{\star}).

Assumption 1.

The function F​(w)𝐹𝑤F(w) is twice continuously differentiable for all w∈ℝd𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

We begin by listing the preliminary lemma.

Lemma 1.

Let Assumption 1 hold. Let Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k} be defined as in (10) depending on the choice of iterates update. Then, for any k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0 there exist constants 0<μ1≤μ20subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇20<\mu_{1}\leq\mu_{2} such that μ1​I⪯Ak⪯μ2​Iprecedes-or-equalssubscript𝜇1𝐼subscript𝐴𝑘precedes-or-equalssubscript𝜇2𝐼\mu_{1}I\preceq A_{k}\preceq\mu_{2}I.

We introduce assumptions and theoretical results for the strongly convex case.

Assumption 2.

There exist positive constants μ𝜇\mu and L𝐿L such that μ​I⪯∇2F​(w)⪯L​I,precedes-or-equals𝜇𝐼superscript∇2𝐹𝑤precedes-or-equals𝐿𝐼\mu I\preceq\nabla^{2}F(w)\preceq LI, ∀w∈ℝdfor-all𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑\forall w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

The following theorem establishes global linear convergence of FLECS under strong convexity.

Theorem 1.

Let Assumptions 1 and 2 hold. Then for iterates {wk}subscript𝑤𝑘\{w_{k}\} generated by Algorithm 5 with 0<αk=α≤μ1μ22​L0subscript𝛼𝑘𝛼subscript𝜇1superscriptsubscript𝜇22𝐿0<\alpha_{k}=\alpha\leq\frac{\mu_{1}}{\mu_{2}^{2}L} we have F​(wk)−F⋆≤(1−α​μ​μ1)k​[F​(w0)−F⋆]𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘superscript𝐹⋆superscript1𝛼𝜇subscript𝜇1𝑘delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤0superscript𝐹⋆F(w_{k})-F^{\star}\leq(1-\alpha\mu\mu_{1})^{k}[F(w_{0})-F^{\star}]~{} for all k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0.

We are now ready to present a convergence guarantee which shows local linear convergence for FLECS under strong convexity. Note that, while Theorem 1 shows that FLECS converges linearly under strong convexity, the rate depends on parameters related to the Hessian approximations. The following local rate is independent of problem conditioning.

‖wk−w∗‖2≤12k​‖w0−w∗‖2superscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑘superscript𝑤21superscript2𝑘superscriptnormsubscript𝑤0superscript𝑤2\|w_{k}-w^{*}\|^{2}\leq\tfrac{1}{2^{k}}\|w_{0}-w^{*}\|^{2}

for all k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0.

We introduce the assumptions for nonconvex case.

Assumption 3.

The function F𝐹F is bounded below by a scalar F^^𝐹\hat{F}.

Assumption 4.

The gradients of F𝐹F are L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous for all w∈ℝn𝑤superscriptℝ𝑛w\in\mathbb{R}^{n}.

The following result shows that FLECS is convergent when problem (1) is nonconvex.

Theorem 3.

Let Assumptions1, 3, 4 hold and w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} be the starting point. Then after T>0𝑇0T>0 iterations of Algorithm 5 with 0<αk=α≤μ1μ22​L0subscript𝛼𝑘𝛼subscript𝜇1superscriptsubscript𝜇22𝐿0<\alpha_{k}=\alpha\leq\frac{\mu_{1}}{\mu_{2}^{2}L}, we have

1T​∑k=0T−1‖∇F​(wk)‖2≤2​[F​(w0)−F^]α​μ1​T⟶T→∞0.1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑇1superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘22delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤0^𝐹𝛼subscript𝜇1𝑇superscript⟶→𝑇0\tfrac{1}{T}\textstyle{\sum}_{k=0}^{T-1}\|\nabla F(w_{k})\|^{2}\leq\tfrac{2[F(w_{0})-\hat{F}]}{\alpha\mu_{1}T}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle T\to\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}0.

5 Numerical Experiments

We present numerical experiments for FLECS on a regularized logistic regression problem:

min⁡{1n​∑i=1n1r​∑j=1rlog⁡(1+exp⁡(−bi​j​ai​jT​w))+μ​‖w‖2},1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑟1subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑇𝑤𝜇superscriptnorm𝑤2\min\left\{\tfrac{1}{n}\textstyle{\sum}_{i=1}^{n}\tfrac{1}{r}\textstyle{\sum}_{j=1}^{r}\log(1+\exp(-b_{ij}a_{ij}^{T}w))+\mu\|w\|^{2}\right\},

where {ai​j,bi​j}j∈[m]subscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝑏𝑖𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑚\left\{a_{ij},b_{ij}\right\}_{j\in[m]} are data points on i𝑖i-th device. We use three datasets from the LIBSVM library [7]: a9a (123123123 features), gisette-scale (500050005000 features) and real-sim (209582095820958 features). We use Top-K𝐾K with k=4​d𝑘4𝑑k=4d and random dithering [2] applied to each matrix column with s=128𝑠128s=128 levels and ∞\infty-norm as a matrix compressors. The performance of FLECS is compared with FedNL.
In our experiments we set regularization parameter μ=10−5𝜇superscript105\mu=10^{-5}, the memory size to m=16𝑚16m=16 and use Bki=0superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑖0B_{k}^{i}=0 as the initial Hessian approximation for FLECS and FedNL for random dithering and Bki=∇fi​(w0)superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘𝑖∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑤0B_{k}^{i}=\nabla f_{i}(w_{0}) for Top-K𝐾K. Truncation parameters were set to ω=10−3,Ω=108formulae-sequence𝜔superscript103Ωsuperscript108\omega=10^{-3},~{}\Omega=10^{8}, and for the FedSONIA update we set ρ=1Ω𝜌1Ω\rho=\frac{1}{\Omega} and α=1𝛼1\alpha=1. For FLECS we use a Truncated L-SR1 Update (Algorithm 1) and a Direct update (Algorithm 2) with learning rate β=1𝛽1\beta=1 as the Hessian learning techniques. For FedNL we use the same β𝛽\beta.
The following three rules were used to compute the search direction pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}: (1) a Truncated Inverse Hessian Approximation (Algorithm 3), (2) FedSONIA (Algorithm 4) with ρk=1Ωsubscript𝜌𝑘1Ω\rho_{k}=\frac{1}{\Omega}, and (3) a regularized update where Bk+1=Bk+1n​∑i=1n‖Cki‖​Isubscript𝐵𝑘1subscript𝐵𝑘1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛normsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑘𝑖𝐼B_{k+1}=B_{k}+\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\|C_{k}^{i}\|I, where Ckisuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑘𝑖C_{k}^{i} are defined in (4). The last update is motivated by [36]. Note, that in the case of FLECS this update does not guarantee positive definiteness of Hessian approximation Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} if m<d𝑚𝑑m<d, but it can still perform well if m𝑚m is large enough.
For FedNL after random dithering the matrix Bk+1subscript𝐵𝑘1B_{k+1} might not be symmetric, so we use 12​(Bk+1+Bk+1T)12subscript𝐵𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘1𝑇\frac{1}{2}(B_{k+1}+B_{k+1}^{T}) as Hessian approximation. In this case, we compare algorithms on the number of bits sent to the server per iteration. For Top-K compression, the communication complexity is roughly the same, so we estimate the performance based on the number of Hessian-vector products.
For the iterates update (3) we set the step-size α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 for all algorithms and datasets except FedSONIA on gisette and real-sim, where we set α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1, as it gives the best performance. Further details specifying algorithm parameters and implementation, as well as additional numerical experiments, can be found in Appendix B.

6 Conclusion

This work presents a new second order framework for Federated Learning problems. The framework employs sketching and compression to ensure communication costs are low, and Hessian approximations are stored on the central server so that memory requirements for the workers is low. Due to the inclusion of partial approximate second order information, the algorithm enjoys favourable convergence guarantees, and numerical experiments show the practical benefits of our approach.

There exist positive constants μ𝜇\mu and L𝐿L such that μ​I⪯∇2F​(w)⪯L​I,precedes-or-equals𝜇𝐼superscript∇2𝐹𝑤precedes-or-equals𝐿𝐼\mu I\preceq\nabla^{2}F(w)\preceq LI, ∀w∈ℝd.for-all𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑\forall w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

The function F𝐹F is bounded below by a scalar F^^𝐹\hat{F}.

Assumption 4.

The gradients of F𝐹F are L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous for all w∈ℝn𝑤superscriptℝ𝑛w\in\mathbb{R}^{n}.

A.4 Proof of Theorem 2

We begin with the technical lemma for FLECS with Truncated Hessian inverse Approximation step (Algorithm 3).

Lemma 2.

Let Assumptions 1, 2 hold and 0≤ω≤μ0𝜔𝜇0\leq\omega\leq\mu, Ω≥LΩ𝐿\Omega\geq L. Then for Hessian approximations Bk+1subscript𝐵𝑘1B_{k+1} we have

‖|Bk+1|ωΩ−∇2f​(w∗)‖F≤‖Bk+1−∇2f​(w∗)‖Fsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐵𝑘1𝜔Ωsuperscript∇2𝑓superscript𝑤Fsubscriptnormsubscript𝐵𝑘1superscript∇2𝑓superscript𝑤F\||B_{k+1}|_{\omega}^{\Omega}-\nabla^{2}f(w^{*})\|_{\text{F}}\leq\|B_{k+1}-\nabla^{2}f(w^{*})\|_{\text{F}}

for all k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0.

Proof.

A.5 Proof of Theorem 3

Theorem 3.

Let Assumptions1, 3, 4 hold and w0subscript𝑤0w_{0} be the starting point. Then after T>0𝑇0T>0 iterations of Algorithm 5 with 0<αk=α≤μ1μ22​L0subscript𝛼𝑘𝛼subscript𝜇1superscriptsubscript𝜇22𝐿0<\alpha_{k}=\alpha\leq\frac{\mu_{1}}{\mu_{2}^{2}L}, we have

1T​∑k=0T−1‖∇F​(wk)‖2≤2​[F​(w0)−F^]α​μ1​T⟶T→∞0.1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑇1superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘22delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝑤0^𝐹𝛼subscript𝜇1𝑇superscript⟶→𝑇0\tfrac{1}{T}\textstyle{\sum}_{k=0}^{T-1}\|\nabla F(w_{k})\|^{2}\leq\tfrac{2[F(w_{0})-\hat{F}]}{\alpha\mu_{1}T}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle T\to\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}0.

Appendix B Additional Numerical Experiments

B.1 Top-K𝐾K Compressor

In this experiment we used Top-K𝐾K compression with k=4​d𝑘4𝑑k=4d on a9a dataset with regularization parameter μ=10−5𝜇superscript105\mu=10^{-5}. We compare FedNL [36] and FLECS in the number of hessian-vector products, since compression cost is roughly the same. For FLECS we set memory size m=16𝑚16m=16 and step-size α=1𝛼1\alpha=1. For both algorithms we set B0i=∇F​(w0)superscriptsubscript𝐵0𝑖∇𝐹subscript𝑤0B_{0}^{i}=\nabla F(w_{0}) and Hessian approximation rate β=1𝛽1\beta=1. In this experiment we omit initialization cost (computation of the full Hessian at starting point) for both algorithms.

B.2 Comparison with DIANA and ADIANA.

In order to compare our framework with DIANA and ADIANA we use random dithering with number of levels s=d𝑠𝑑s=\sqrt{d} and p=∞𝑝p=\infty. For FLECS we set hyperparametes as: m=1𝑚1m=1, β=1𝛽1\beta=1, α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 and initialize Hessian approximations with 00.

For DIANA and ADIANA we used theoretical parameters L=1/4𝐿14L=1/4 and strong convexity constant μ=10−5𝜇superscript105\mu=10^{-5}. For these methods we used an original code provided by authors [27, 43].

B.3 Top-K𝐾K vs Random Dithering

In this subsection we want to compare Top-K𝐾K compressor with random dithering for FLECS. We set hyperparametes as: m=16𝑚16m=16, β=1𝛽1\beta=1, α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 and initialize Hessian approximations with ∇2f​(w0)superscript∇2𝑓subscript𝑤0\nabla^{2}f(w_{0}). We use Top-K𝐾K with k=4​d𝑘4𝑑k=4d and random dithering with s=128𝑠128s=128 and p=∞𝑝p=\infty, so communication cost per iteration is roughly the same. In this experiment we omit initialization cost (computation of the full Hessian at starting point) for both algorithms.

B.4 Dependence on the Memory Size

Here we compare different memory sizes for FLECS on a9a dataset. We use random dithering with parameters s=128𝑠128s=128 and p=∞𝑝p=\infty. Hyperparametes set as β=1𝛽1\beta=1, α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 and initialize Hessian approximations initialized with 00.

Appendix C Compressors

FLECS allows several different compression operators. In this section we give definitions and provide examples of possible compressors for our framework.

C.1 Unbiased Compressors.

Definition 2.

A random operator 𝒞:ℝd×m→ℝd×m:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚\mathcal{C}:~{}\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}\to\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} satisfying

𝔼𝒬[𝒞(X)]=X,𝔼𝒞[∥𝒞(X)∥F2]≤(ω+1)∥X∥F2],{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{Q}}\left[\mathcal{C}(X)\right]=X,~{}~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{C}}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(X)\|_{\text{F}}^{2}\right]\leq(\omega+1)\|X\|_{\text{F}}^{2}], (17)

for all X∈ℝd×m𝑋superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚X\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} is a unbiased compressor operator.

Random dithering for vectors (ω𝜔\omega-quantization) [2], applied to each column of the matrix, is an example of unbiased compressors that we used in our experiments.

C.2 Biased compressors.

Definition 3.

A random operator 𝒞:ℝd×m→ℝd×m:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚\mathcal{C}:~{}\mathbb{R}^{d\times m}\to\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} satisfying

𝔼𝒞[𝒞(X)]≤∥X∥F,𝔼𝒞[∥𝒞(X)∥F2]≤(1−δ)∥X∥F2],{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{C}}\left[\mathcal{C}(X)\right]\leq\|X\|_{\text{F}},~{}~{}{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathcal{C}}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(X)\|_{\text{F}}^{2}\right]\leq(1-\delta)\|X\|_{\text{F}}^{2}], (18)

for all X∈ℝd×m𝑋superscriptℝ𝑑𝑚X\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times m} is a contractive compressor operator.

In our experiments we use Top-K𝐾K as a contractive compressor.
